Situation1: They share only one open evening before a busy travel week.
Expectation2: Respect the privacy and confidentiality of the people you are helping
Situation2: They are sorting files that contain detailed medical histories that must not be disclosed.
Story: Tonight is the only evening this week that Alex and I both have free. He’s been looking forward to it, dropping hints about a cozy dinner and maybe a movie at home. I promised him we’d make the most of it, just us, no distractions. But as I’m getting ready to leave work, my phone buzzes—a last-minute request from the volunteer coordinator. They’re short-handed at the clinic, and they need someone to help sort confidential medical files. I know how important it is to keep those records private, to respect the trust people place in us. I can’t just say no, but I also can’t break my promise to Alex. My heart pounds as I picture his disappointed face, and at the same time, I feel the weight of responsibility for the people who count on our discretion. I stand in the hallway, torn, the evening stretching ahead of me, split between two worlds that both need me right now.
